title: 114_hr4888
content: The Act may be cited as the "Ending Homelessness Act of 2016". Congressional findings are also included. The Congress finds that despite initial progress in reducing veteran homelessness with increased funding, overall national goals for ending homelessness have stalled due to lack of funding. In 2015, there were 564,708 people experiencing homelessness in the US, including 83,170 chronically homeless individuals. Homelessness increased by 3% in major city Continuum of Care programs from 2014 to 2015, highlighting a crisis in many urban areas. The Congress acknowledges the crisis of homelessness in major cities, with some declaring it an emergency. The Federal Government is urged to renew its commitment to end homelessness nationally. Title IV of the McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act is amended to include a new subtitle called "5-Year Path To End Homelessness" with emergency relief funding provided in section 451. Title IV of the McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act is amended to include a new subtitle called "5-Year Path To End Homelessness" with $1 billion allocated for emergency relief grants over five fiscal years to address the unmet needs of homeless populations in high-need jurisdictions through direct appropriations and formula grants. The new subtitle "5-Year Path To End Homelessness" under Title IV of the McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act aims to allocate $1 billion for emergency relief grants over five fiscal years to address the unmet needs of homeless populations in high-need jurisdictions by using data on poverty rates, affordable housing shortages, overcrowded housing units, and unsheltered homeless counts. The Secretary will allocate grants to collaborative applicants based on a funding formula established within 60 days of the enactment of the new subtitle "5-Year Path To End Homelessness" under Title IV of the McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act. The grants will be distributed based on a funding formula established within 60 days of the enactment of the new subtitle "5-Year Path To End Homelessness" under Title IV of the McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act. Collaborative applicants receiving grants must use the funds for eligible activities under specific sections and comply with a permanent supportive housing requirement. Collaborative applicants receiving grants must use at least 75 percent of the grant amount for permanent supportive housing, including capital costs, rental subsidies, and services. The Secretary may exempt applicants from this requirement if chronic homelessness has been eliminated in the area or if there is sufficient permanent supportive housing in development. The Secretary will review exemption requests within 60 days. Only 5% of the grant can be used for administrative expenses. Recipients must implement a Housing First approach. The grant amounts will be used for a Housing First model for homeless assistance. Expiring contracts for housing will be treated as expiring contracts for renewal funding. A report on the grant program's design and implementation must be submitted to Congress by September 1, 2016. The Secretary and the United States Interagency Council on Homelessness must submit semiannual reports to Congress detailing the grant program's operation, grants made, and activities funded. Collaborative applicants receiving grants must provide necessary information to the Secretary for reporting purposes. "SEC. 452. SPECIAL PURPOSE VOUCHERS." "Appropriation of $500,000,000 from Treasury for rental assistance under section 8(o) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 for homeless individuals and households. Up to 10% may be used for administrative fees." The Secretary will establish policies for administrative fees under the United States Housing Act of 1937 to assist homeless persons find suitable housing. Assistance will be allocated based on geographical need and administrative performance of public housing agencies. Funding renewal for rental contracts is also addressed. Renewal funding for rental assistance contracts under the United States Housing Act of 1937 will be funded through the section 8 tenant-based rental assistance account. The Secretary has the authority to waive or specify alternative requirements to ensure homeless persons can access housing with rental assistance, excluding certain provisions related to fair housing, nondiscrimination, labor standards, and the environment. The Secretary requires public housing agencies to assist applicants and tenants in avoiding homelessness. "SEC. 453. OUTREACH FUNDING." "Appropriation of $100,000,000 from Treasury for fiscal years 2017-2021 to provide outreach and services for homeless individuals. Grants awarded on a competitive basis to collaborative applicants prioritizing innovative staff use." The Secretary will establish criteria for grants under this section within 60 days of enactment. Grant amounts must be used for case managers, social workers, or staff for homeless outreach. Distribution of funds will occur within 30 days of criteria establishment. The Housing Trust Fund is established. The Housing Trust Fund is appropriated $1 billion annually for fiscal year 2017 and beyond, to be used for housing purposes. Additionally, $50 million is allocated for rental assistance each year, to be used in conjunction with grant funds awarded under the same section. The Housing Trust Fund is appropriated $1 billion annually for housing purposes, with $50 million allocated for rental assistance each year (12 U.S.C. 4568). Tenant rent contributions are limited to ensure a minimum of 75 percent, with all rental housing units legally bound to maintain a set contribution towards rent by residing families. The Housing Trust Fund allocates $1 billion annually for housing purposes, with $50 million for rental assistance. Tenant rent contributions are limited to 30% of the family's adjusted income. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will issue regulations to implement the Federal Housing Enterprises Financial Safety and Soundness Act within 90 days of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FUNDS TO ALIGN HEALTH AND HOUSING SYSTEMS. Funding of $20,000,000 is available for technical assistance under the McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act to expand the Healthcare and Housing Systems Integration Initiative. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will collaborate with the United States Interagency Council on Homelessness and the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The initiative aims to integrate policies and funding between Medicaid programs, behavioral health providers, and housing providers to create supportive housing opportunities. State Medicaid program directors and Governors will be engaged in the expansion efforts. The Secretary collaborates with State Medicaid program directors, Governors, and relevant State agencies to increase Medicaid financing for supportive services for homeless individuals. Priority is given to States and localities with the highest numbers of chronically homeless persons. The McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act is amended to authorize appropriations for each fiscal year. The United States Interagency Council on Homelessness is permanently extended, and an emergency designation is included. SEC. 8. EMERGENCY DESIGNATION. The amounts provided by this Act and its amendments are designated as an emergency requirement under specific legislative acts.
